attr.q:
Consider a random experiment with a sample space

```math
S=\{1,2,3,\cdots\}.
```
Suppose that we know:

```math
P(k)=P(\{k\})=\frac{c}{3^k}, \quad \textrm{for} \quad k=1,2,\cdots,
```

where $`c`$  is a constant number.

1. Find $`c`$
2. Find $`P(\{2,4,6\})`$
3. Find $`P(\{3,4,5,\cdots\})`$
attr.a:
### 1

Using geometric sum, following must hold

```math
\cfrac{\cfrac{c}{3}}{1 - \cfrac{c}{3}} = 1
```

Therefore $`c`$ is 1.

### 2

```math
\begin{aligned}
  &P(\{2,4,6\}) \\
  &=P(2) + P(4) + P(6) \\
  &=\dfrac{2}{3^2} + \dfrac{2}{3^4} + \dfrac{2}{3^6} \\
  &=\dfrac{182}{729}
\end{aligned}
```

### 3

```math
\begin{aligned}
  &P(\{3,4,5,\cdots \}) \\
  &=1 - P(1) - P(2) \\
  &=1 - \dfrac{2}{3} - \dfrac{2}{9} \\
  &=\dfrac{1}{9}
\end{aligned}
```
